Thanks, it does.


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Jeff
Clune
Sent: Saturday, January 16, 2010 9:19 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Is environmental information helpful for
developmental complexity?


  

Hi Ken-

By geometric information I simply mean the global coordinates for each node
fed into the CPPN. 

Environmental information is almost everything else: the temperature,
pressure, concentration of potassium, oxygen level, etc.

Hope that helps clarify things.

Kind regards,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
jclune@... <mailto:jclune%40msu.edu> 
www.msu.edu/~jclune

> From: Ken Lloyd <kalloyd@wattsys. <mailto:kalloyd%40wattsys.com> com>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com"
<neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com>
> Date: Sat, 16 Jan 2010 19:19:48 -0700
> To: "neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com"
<neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com>
> Subject: RE: [neat] Re: Is environmental information helpful for
developmental
> complexity?
> 
> Jeff,
> 
> I want to make sure I understand your point. By "geometric information",
> are you referring to metrics of a spatio-temporal nature, such as time,
> location or orientation? And by "environmental information" are you
> referring to thermodynamic information, such as temperature, pressure,
> energy, entropy?
> 
> The reason I ask has to do with understanding exchanges (perturbations) of
> energy, information and entropy between the network representing the
system
> of interest, through the network of interfaces (input, output, hidden,
bias)
> and its context, representing the sources and sinks of that energy,
> information, and entropy in space-time. The contexts I speak of may
> represent your "increasingly complex coordinate frames" - as measureable,
> meaningful spaces, topologies, manifolds or domains.
> 
> The CPPN can encode category theoretic functors, but in doing so it needs
to
> encode both the category and its objects (say, by using tensor-functions
in
> its ordering schema). As such it may encode elements, structure, behavior
> and morphism.
> 
> Ken Lloyd
> 
> From: neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com
[mailto:neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com] On Behalf Of
Jeff
> Clune
> Sent: Saturday, January 16, 2010 5:57 PM
> To: neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com
> Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Is environmental information helpful for
> developmental complexity?
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Hello Ken-
> 
> I am fully on board with the idea that using global geometric information
> makes development easier. The question is, as you point out, whether we
> should take the hard view that such information is the only thing that
> evolution needs. 
> 
> Thinking along these lines, there are two related but importantly distinct
> questions: 
> 
> 1) Can evolution produce all desired forms only with geometric
information?
> 2) Does evolution have an easier time if you combine both geometric
> information and environmental information?
> 
> My post was more getting at the second question. My hunch is that it may
in
> some cases be easier to base heuristics off of environmental information
> than to make the same distinction only using geometric information. But,
> even if that is true, it does not undermine the huge advance of your CPPN
> work that shows how much easier development is if we provide global
> geometric information (and evolve increasingly complex coordinate frames
> from it). 
> 
> So we are in full agreement about this statement:
> 
>> Yet I believe such functionality can complement and extend CPPNs without
>> replacing their central role in encoding neural structures.
> 
> I also agree with you that we need to get learning working in conjunction
> with evolution to produce intelligent neural networks. This statement is
> largely true because the learning takes care of figuring out things that
are
> changing on a timescale that is too fast for evolution to get a bead on.
> 
> -jeff
> 
>> 
>> 
>> ken
>> 
>> --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, Jeff Clune
> <jclune@...> wrote:
>>> 
>>> Hello all-
>>> 
>>> The article below is interesting. It suggests that lung cells know to
> become
>>> lung cells based on the air passing back and forth over them. It is
>>> intriguing in the context of HyperNEAT because it shows that sometimes
>>> nature does not use geometric position (provided by complex protein
>>> patterning) to make differentiation decisions, but uses environmental
> cues.
>>> Of course, HyperNEAT could create the same end product just with
> positional
>>> information, but it might be easier to accomplish this with simple
>>> environmental-based tricks like this one. Thoughts?
>>> 
>>> New Scientist
>>> Breath of fresh air transforms stem cells
>>> 
>>> 14:32 09 November 2009 by Andy Coghlan
>>> For similar stories, visit the Stem Cells Topic Guide
>>> Mimicking the environment experienced by cells in the windpipe is enough
> to
>>> transform stem cells into a range of different lung cells. Such
> "physical"
>>> techniques could be used to create specialised tissues when growth
> factors
>>> alone aren't enough.
>>> 
>>> Lindsey Van Haute of the Free University of Brussels (VUB) in Belgium
and
>>> colleagues spread human embryonic stem cells onto a porous membrane. The
>>> cells were fed from beneath by nutrients and from above by a fluid that
>>> encouraged them to multiply. Removing two chemicals from the growth
fluid
>>> kickstarted differentiation.
>>> 
>>> Four days later, the team removed the fluid covering the cells, leaving
> them
>>> open to the air while still being sustained and supported from below, as
>>> they would be in the trachea. After 24 days the cells had developed
> surface
>>> proteins that identified them as specific types of lung cell, including
>>> alveolar cells, which allow the exchange of gases, and cilia, which
expel
>>> bacteria and dirt.
>>> 
>>> Physical influence
>>> 
>>> "Our study proves differentiation into lung cells is influenced by
> physical
>>> forces," says Van Haute. Previously, stem cells have been made to
>>> differentiate into lung cells using a cocktail of different growth
> factors,
>>> but Haute says using physical forces might be simpler.
>>> 
>>> "Physical forces are certainly a factor in getting the lung lining to be
>>> fully functional," says Anne Bishop at Imperial College London, who has
> made
>>> alveolar cells from mouse stem cells using growth factors alone. "But I
> find
>>> it difficult to believe that raw stem cells would differentiate through
> to
>>> these uncommon types of cells solely in response to physical forces."
>>> 
>>> Haute's team plans to use the cells they created to study lung diseases,
>>> such as cystic fibrosis. Such cells might one day be used to treat
people
>>> with damaged lung tissue, but only if the cells can be made from a
> person's
>>> own tissue. This could be done by converting the cells first into
induced
>>> pluripotent stem cells.
>>> 
>>> Journal reference: Respiratory Research, DOI: 10.1186/1465-9921-10-105
>>> 
>>> 
>>> 
>>> 
>>> Cheers,
>>> Jeff Clune
>>> 
>>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
>>> jclune@...
>>> www.msu.edu/~jclune
>>> 
>> 
>> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
>
